Translation of 楚竹書・姑成家父(en) into English.

p.seg: Kucheng Jiafu served Duke Li (of Jin) as an official,
he was orderly in his procedures and upright and swift in his diligence,
therefore he got disliked by Duke Li.
Duke Li was unprincipled,
and oppressive towards Baiyu,
(so that) Baiyu opposed him.
Kucheng Jiafu straightened (put back under control) Baiyu together with his kin, the Three Xi,
not letting them oppose (the Duke).
He himself appointed men of the official class to serve as resident officials,
and took care of them from dawn to dusk,
causing them to have (=to abide to) the rules of ruler and subject.
The Three Xi abided to their position,
so that they corrected the transgressions of the officials and of the population,
exerting effort in favor of the Duke’s house.
Lian Shu wanted to stir troubles,
so he instilled worries into the Three Xi.
He told Kucheng Jiafu:
‘(you should be thinking of) doing things for your family/progeny,
and (instead) for what are you exercising so much effort?
There is a saying to this purpose:
“Unsuccessful all along
(because of) an unprincipled government”.
(It is) a crumbling house that will quickly suppress (=crash) you (?).
You should make plans about it.”
Kucheng Jiafu said:
“How could I dare to feel unsuccessful in my (or: and thereby [only]) working for my progeny?
I stand upright and act straightforwardly,
pondering far to plan for the future.
Even if I am not successful for my progeny,
if by being principled
I have to face death in a short time,
what is the damage?”
Lian Shu then withdrew,
and told Duke Li:
“The kin of the Three Xi is (too) strong,
they took your people
and do not listen to your orders,
a great damage will ensue.”
The Duke was frightened
and so ordered Zhang Yuqiao [...]
Xi Qi heard about it,
and told Kucheng Jiafu:
“With our kin, the Three Xi, with [...]
to the ruler,
if we are successful
we will obtain control of the gods of the soil and land of the Jin state [=we will get hold of the state of Jin]
if we are unsuccessful
we will get (a way to) escape and leave.
誰不以厚?” Who among the feudal lords will not then treat us generously?”
Kucheng Jiafu said:
“It cannot be done.
The lord valued me and gave me (his) people,
so that I could take care of them.
Now if I am not able to take care of them
and because of this I harm my ruler,
there is no greater damage than this.
Even if we obtain a way to escape and leave,
as we are not able to serve our ruler,
which ruler under Heaven
will ever want to take us with him?
At the beginning, I set myself unwaveringly on taking care of the people,
intending therefore to establish for long my master and ruler
and averting troubles.
Now my master and ruler is unsatisfied with me,
and so in return I (should) hate him.
If I have nothing with which to carry on the government of the Duke’s affairs,
even if I die,
how could I escape?
I have heard that (good) ministers
must make the ruler satisfied about them
and (then) could have a future for their progeny.
Kucheng Jiafu then kept Baiyu under control
and did not let his kin to follow him and went to the court.
Zhang Yuqiao plotted,
coming from the Duke’s court,
to gather men in Baiyu and bring them (back) in (to the Duke’s court) (to cause an incident)
(so that the Duke would) imprison them.
Kucheng Jiafu arrested Zhang Yuqiao,
brought him into fetters to the court,
together with his wife and his mother.
